This review is a little lengthy, so if you just want a quick summary of why I recommend Call of Juarez skip the Results and read from there.Techland starts the series with the epic western mystery action adventure. Call of Jaurez draws you in to a world of hardship and torment that plagues the old west. In particularly how racism and corruption of the older days impacted the life of Billy Candle, a young man. Story:Call of Juarez is a Western style action game. The story is incredibly interesting, but honestly takes a while to get into. Call of Juarez is a western mystery surrounding the story of the gold of Juarez. The story surrounds the protagonist Billy Candle, a boy without a father, from the little town of Hope (an ironic name). Billy ends up being caught up in a mystery of whether he may or may not have murdered his parents. The death of Billy’s parents and the prejudice of the Hope forces Billy to go on the lamb. Reverend Ray, brother to Billy’s mother’s lover, hunts Billy for this crime. In order to start a new life Billy is set for Juarez, but will Reverend Ray catch him?Campaign:In the campaign you play both Billy and Ray throughout. Billy as he is on the lamb and the Reverend as he hunts him down. There are fifteen chapters to the game, and they only become longer as you progress further. Each chapter begins with a dialogue read either by Billy or Ray. The story is rather gripping, but I didn't start really caring much about the characters until about Chapter VII. The game has some levels that are incredibly long, while others than are very short. I would recommend saving a lot during the game as for me the Auto-Save feature did not work. What is most interesting is how the levels are designed; some of them are essentially open world while others are pathways. For an older game, 2006, the levels can be quite expansive and rather innovative. Some of these levels will require you to solve puzzles, other will require you to complete tasks, but most the time you will just be running and gunning like a madman. Gameplay:Once you’ve mastered the basic mechanics of the game there is not much more too it. Billy Candle should always use the Bow and Arrow as it causes time to slow for him. While Reverend Ray should always quick draw as it causes time to slow for him. There are many different types of weapons, but you will notice that as the game progresses they are all essentially the same and pistols with quick reload are always the best bet. Rifles win over shotguns, because you will never be close to enemies that need a big dose of Lead (Pb). And on the incredibly rare occasion you find one, a scoped rifle is the best gun. The weapons break over time, so you will be constantly throwing away your guns and essentially selecting the same ones.  The movement is rather clunky, but for a 2006 title it does a good job. If you are interested in getting into Call of Juarez series (although I have not played Bound in Blood) Gunslinger is a completely different game with no references to the original. So you could start wherever you want and just work your way back to this one.Hints:>Despite there being many interesting and cool guns, they all do the same basic damage and essentially there is no reason to use anything other than the Quick Reload weapons and the Bow. >Just remember with Reverend Ray you can always quick draw, just put away your guns, wait a few moments, and then right click your mouse.Difficulty Problems:I beat this game on Medium Difficulty, but I would say I was really upset I couldn't play it on Hard Difficulty. I wanted to, but the first episode where you had to run away from the rain of bullets was essentially impossible, so because of that one annoying part I had to play the whole game on medium. Results:If you like Westerns, you can get past the mechanics/graphics of older generation games, and are interested in an epic adventure then this is the game for you. The game presents a lot of challenges, mystery, character development, open world environments, and combat. The game was incredibly easy and I never was really posed with a single challenge, although a lack of challenge just makes the game seem like a 80s action movie. Call of Jaurez is a fun game coupled with a fantastic campaign. I recommend Call of Jaurez, especially if you can get it for a good sale. Pros:+Interesting story, characters and level design.+Nice variety of weapons (despite you only ever really using one type of them)+No limit to “Quick Draw” Ability+A long campaign that requires a variety of tactics and battle types.+Being able to swing with your whip from tree to tree.Cons:-My game glitched making me unable to finish the final scene, but you can easily watch it online (despite it not being as gratifying as completing it yourself). -The game can take a while to load even though its an old game.-The dialogue at the beginning of each episode is read incredibly slow-The guns lose duration and break, which is incredibly annoying as some weapons, like the scoped rifle, are near impossible to find.-Some of the levels are so big you find yourself running between zones for a couple minutes with no enemies.

												Call of Juarez is one of those games already fading from memory. Solid shooting mechanics mix with poor level design while potentially interesting protagonists are bludgeoned with ho-hum enemies. Sadly some of the game's signature features, such as the slow-motion focus shooting, are hugely overused and actually drag the game down.Call of Juarez's plot unfolds from each of two character perspectives. The first, Billy, is a worthless do-nothing that finds himself wandering back home after years of searching for the mythical treasure of Juarez.He's an entirely annoying character in spirit and nearly all of the levels designed for him involve some sort of sneaking or rock climbing expedition, which only compounds the issue.he second character, Reverend Ray, is a preacher with a dark past that has actively been seeking redemption through prayer and church. When his brother is killed, supposedly by Billy, his more violent side pushes to the front again as he begins the chase for righteous vengeance across the wild, slaughtering any wicked men in his way. The violent road eventually leads to unfortunate consequences as Revered Ray's convictions and faith are turned upside down. Both characters are given skills to help differentiate their styles of play, Ray being the run and gun and Billy being the sneak about, but the techniques aren't necessarily welcome.One of the game's more interesting features, called concentration mode, also ends up being one of the game's worst enemies. When activated, time will slow down for Ray after drawing his guns. The recharge time on Ray's ability is too fast, allowing you to simply wait and use it over and over. Having a special ability like this should actually be special rather than standard.While the special focus ability is optional, the levels, unfortunately, are not.  The corridor shooter sections with Reverend Ray running point aren't necessarily all bad. Running and gunning through an Old West town is fun. But corridor shooting can only get you so far these days. Even worse are the levels with jumping puzzles and whip swinging. Visually Call of Juarez is decent enough though it won't win any awards. It looked pretty good when it was originally announced, but these days it's mid-range at best. Character models, faces particularly, are the best the game has to offer. Environments are blocky and offer up some strange texturing creating passable play areas. Multiplayer also has its moments, though most of them are more cheap thrills than deep gaming. Call of Juarez might appeal to you, but it's not the Wild West fun I was hoping for.

												If I were to some this game up in a sentence:  Frustrating but rewarding.  That's the feeling that permeates my experience playing.  Some controls and features have a tendency to cause a lot frustrated cursing.  But after those moments are eventually conquered, a rush of excitement is usually the reward. Pretty much the main reason I keep playing.  A psychotic priest that quotes bible passages while shooting hombres.-Quick, exciting gunfights filled with tension as well as adrenaline.-A pretty good learning curve.  It takes a while to get used to, but it doesn't through you into situations that you don't feel entirely unprepared for.-Pretty entertaining story.  But I'm mostly in it just to shoot people.Cons:-Billy Candle.  A bland, whiny little waste of code that exists to drive the plot forward and introduce new game mechanics that usually don't involve shooting bandits in the nuts.-The whip mechanics.  Trying for an Indiana Jones vibe.  Doesn't quite stick the landing.  Literally.  I can not tell you how many times I've died because I didn't swing far enough to make the ledge, or fell to my death because the whip didn't actually grab the branch.  Probably the most frustrating aspect of gameplay.-Kind of glitchy.  This might due to the games age.  I don't mind glitches normally, usually find them pretty funny. At the beginning of the 7th generation of consoles, developers crammed all sorts of differing play styles into their games hoping to impress consumers with variety.  This leads to games sometimes feeling more like glorified tech demos than straight Action/Shooter/Platformer/ect. Again, not the end of the world, but hurts the final product.-Father Ray is pretty much only half the game.  The other half is stealthy, whip-swingy douchbag Billy Candle.  Missed opportunity.All in all.  A fun western shoot'em up that loses it's way a bit under the weight of it's own ambition.  Totally reccommended for fans of the genre, so long as they're willing to put up with some of the games idiosynchrasies.7/10

												     I'll open by getting this out of the way, I haven't played The Cartel. Reviews were negative and the whole first person,GTA knockoff thing didn't appeal to me. I've only played this, Bound in Blood, and Gunslinger. So, on to this game.     I think this is the best, and worst game in the Call of Juarez series. First, the good stuff. With the exception of the stiff facial animation, the graphics are kinda neat for a 2007 game (obviously aside from Crysis). The foliage actually looks better than most games I've played, and the screen space sun rays make for some cool lighting. The shadows are actually higher resolution than the sequels. But the thing that most impressed me, regarding the visuals, was the dust effect from bullet impacts. In other games, you shoot a tree, the ground, whatever, and the bullet kicks up a small cloud of dust. Call of Juarez goes one step further. If you fire a bullet, an arrow, or even use Billy's whip on one of those dust clouds, it will spread out and away from the projectile. I love the dynamic effect this has on shootouts.     How's the gameplay? Pretty good, when you're in combat. As Ray McCall you can dual wield pistols and occasionally activate a sort of bullet-time for a few seconds. As Billy, the game enters slow-mo every time you aim your bow. Levels tend to be fairly wide open with plenty of space to move around. But there was one thing I could not stand, the duals, which, like the sequels, were a real pain. Overall, the combat is fun, though difficult. However, this game isn't all fighting. It also has stealth and platforming sections, but these were worse than the duals. Enemies seemed to spot me no matter what I did. And there's nothing more infuriating in this game than thinking you've just escaped, and a sharp sound indicates you were caught, triggering an instant fail state. If you manage to get past the stealth sections without rage quitting, then the platforming level might just do you in. Jumping gaps feels awkward, and while using your whip to swing on branches SOUNDS cool, it's almost impossible to accurately determine where you'll land. I lost count of the number of times I fell to my death because of the clumsy first-person platforming.     The story is alright, better than Gunslinger, but worse than Bound in Blood.     I recommend this game IF you can get past the frustrating platforming and stealth levels, and have fun with the combat and visuals.

												Back in 2006 Techland were still relatively unknown. Having released Chrome before hand, a shooter that got a rather mixed reaction. They followed up with Call of Juarez. Going even further into their own direction they decided to focus on a wild west themed shooter built on their own in house engine. What we got was a gorgeous looking shooter that palyed like a spagetti western with bits of Robert Rodriguez attitude here and there. I bought the original retail release back in 2006 and after finishing it, I hadn't ever really returned to it. But, recently I bought the game again on STEAM and decided to give the entire series (yes even The Cartel) a proper rerun. With the first Call of Juarez I'm still in love with the verys imple and direct style of the game. While at times still wonderfully beautiful in it's visuals, it still comes up short on character animations, which were a bit stiff even back in 2006. And at times, the character models even look a bit rough, as if they are not up to the same level of quality as the levels themselves. The levels... vast, wide open areas. They don't offer much (or any) in the way of exploration. But, they are large enough to give you the feeling of how large the wild west was. The story, is good. Nothing great, but nothing bad. It's solid writing, decent voice acting... but nothing I want to spoil or get into. But, the game is worth playing simply for Reverand Ray alone. His character is and will always be the best part of the first two CoJ titles. The other main character Billy, is... okay. But, at times he's more annoying then engaging and a lot of the time I simply wanted to return to Ray. Gameplay is were the game falters. Switching back and forth between Ray and Billy, offering up variety in gameplay and level design. Something most shooters struggle with. With Ray, it's a more straight forward shooter experience. He's a brawler, strong and a very talented gunfighter. Billy, is weak, but fast and sneaky. And very skilled with a bow and arrow. While the variety is nice, it's also here that problems arise. Ray's levels are wonderful. WIth his armor chestplate able to deflect shots, and his concentration mode being able to down multiple enemies quickly. Issues arise during the "dualing", never a great setup... a mouse cursor bug on mordern OS causes the game to be incredibly frustrating during these parts. As for Billy, while the platforming works very well and the stealth is actually done very well also. Billy is very weak, and more often then not they throw you into combat situations as him. Often expecting you to try and just run from them instead of fighting. But, as weak as he is even one lucky shot as you're trying to run (or ride away on a horse) can kill you. A flawed gem, but one I'm enjoying replaying.

												To recommend or not to recommend, an impossible question without knowing who is asking and who much they're thinking of spending. The last six and a half years have be relatively kind to Call of Juarez but it is definitely one for the genre or series fans rather than everyone and the current Steam price of £14 that I'm seeing is definitely too much and I'm glad I didn't pay that much. Mechanicially the game is quite interesting. The plot and the mechanics revolve arround two seperate characters, the young agile sneaky Billy and old psychopathic Reverend Ray. Billy's levels revolve arround stealth and movement, Ray's arround shooting everything that moves before it can shoot you. Neither is perfect, Billy's stealth ability to hide in bushes for instance is particularly dependant on the level designers whim rather than any sense of logic and the Reverend's bullettime ability with pistols is obscenely overpowered, makes no sense at all and breaks up the shooting almost as much as Fallout 3's V.A.T.S. system. So yeah, the run and gun character plays like something out of an RPG... Honestly, it isn't as bad as that sounds though and I had fun playing his levels, and Billy's for that matter, throughout the game. The fact that the mechanics are a bit different from the norm and have their own particular feel is really what has kept this game feeling fresh. It also doesn't outstay its welcome, which admittedly is a flattering way of saying it is short but short and good is a heck of a lot better than long and boring any day. Particularly if you're not paying the sort of money that would demand a game that is both long and good.Plot wise, well it is a western and as such it probably can't be expected to deliver too much and it doesn't really. Two fairly interesting main characters, Ray in particular wouldn't be that interesting just as a background character but as a viewpoint character he is a minor stroke of genus. Sadly the supporting cast are wooden cutouts at best. The female characters are particular badly done by. There are four in total that I noticed: there is Suzy, who works as a prosititute and who basically only exists to have her gun stolen by Billy while she is trying to "welcome you home" behind her pimp's back. Then there is Billy's mother who is brutally murdered before she even has a chance to appear in the game and exists pretty much only as an example of the woman in the fridge trope. Then there is the sheriff's wife who is a damsel that must be rescued from some random dudes for reasons. Then there is Molly, the love interest and main female character who is pretty much the most generic boring useless damsel in distress you could hope to meet. If any of these characters had anything approaching an actual character then I must have missed it. As a side note the game should probably come with a trigger warning for sexual violence since it can't seem to shut up about it. I guess they were trying to make it sound gritty but it is completely overdone.Would I recommend it? Well for all my gripes I did have fun and for the couple of quid I paid for it I easily got value for money out of it. I didn't pay £14 for it though and I wouldn't recommend that you do either but as a game that is still fun and interesting, so yeah, I'll recommend it.

												I really wanted to like this one because I loved the sequel (Bound in Blood), which I played first. Overall, the production values were great. Voice acting, art style, story, etc. Switching between characters on both sides of the fence also made for interesting gamplay styles and narrative. However, some of the gameplay mechanics are very flawed. Random difficulty spikes and changes in mechanics like fist fighting weren't really fun. There are some stretches of the game where you have to go a long time without heath pickups, and whether you take damage or not is dependent on a random dice roll of whether or not enemies hit your armor or head. The maps are generally linear but whenever new path ways open up, it's not always evident where you are supposed to backtrack to find a new path. This leads to a lot of wandering around, and if you are in a sequence where you have a time limit, finding out where you need to go may lead to failure. There are also stuck in geometry problems if you wander off the the path. It was probably great at the time it was new but it  seems like the game didn't age very well by today's standards. By the end it felt like a boring (but very difficult) slog. I'm still glad I got to get closure on this story, but if you are interested in a western themed shooter, play the sequel Bound in Blood first, and then decide whether you want to play this one to get the full story. The sequel is actually a prequel story-wise, so you don't really lose anything by playing them out of order, in my opinion. Playing this one really made me appreciate the sequel. The devs learned many lessons and improved upon pretty much every gameplay aspect.

Oldtimer with some troubles!First of, yes, this game is old, and it sometimes shows. Especially finetuning the game to get it work on modern machines under Windows 7, 8 or 10... You might get the game running, and then you notice, the sound isn't online... next you notice there are graphical glitches. Thank god there are workarounds for this, and if you have some skill in research you will find them quick.The story is good with two protagonists, who are antagonistic. They are old school antiheroes of the italian western style. It's a love/hate thing in this game. Sympathies are misplaced though because both protagonists are more or less... well let's just say they are both not the kind of neighbor anyone wants to have close by. One is a scoundrel and loafer, while the other is a bigot and former gunslinger turned priest. This should be enough about the two protagonists. The story that unfolds during the game is nice though, but you have to kill a lot of people in either forms, they are different in style and in motive. Both are driven by revenge. I played the game when it came out back then, it was fun to play. Now there is of course the feeling of a rerun. Which might scratch a bit on the patina of the game.There is a lot to like about this game, first, the characters are developing during the game. You will see a story and misunderstanding that only unfolds during the run of the game. It is a FPS game, yes, but also it is an adventure.To modern standards this game is a bit dated, it shows in several ways, smudgy textures, not so well in supporting higher resolutions, and then there is the trouble with soundsystems and startup. But with a big "But!", this game is fun once you get it started. It reminds a lot on the time when the game was first introduced. Which has been ten years ago. If you like hardcore FPS with some puzzles and twists, some agility parcours and a good backgroundstory, then this game is cut out for you. Besides it's inexpensive and offers a lot for that.RecommendedOn my personal score this game has on a scale between 1 and 15 a rock solid 9 Points. Which would be a C+ or 3+ if put into notes. It's not the perfect experience from back then, but it still has a lot of charm. Even though it's technically far behind, you still can play it and have fun with the game.

												Call of D̶u̶t̶y̶  Juarez is a m̶i̶l̶i̶t̶a̶r̶y̶  western themed first-person shooter. The levels are pretty linear and slow-motion is used constantly.Real talk tho, this game is good.	The story covers most of the usual western fare; Horseback chases, a train scene, a lone badass laying waste to the population of an entire town, everything is covered fairly well. The voice acting and writing is nicely done, though the written text can get a bit sloppy, such as the unforgivable "of" in the place of "have".	An interesting thing to note is that the game doesn't let the player abuse corpses and innocents, sometimes punishing the behavior with a game over. This can get annoying during particularly intense battles. If I accidentally click on a corpse, I'll be prevented from shooting for a second while the character I'm playing as tells me that he won't do it, and sometimes that moment is enough to let something kill me, but that's the thing; From a story perspective, it makes sense. Both of the playable characters have established personalities, and neither of them is a heartless enough ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to disregard their morals, even when it may be convenient.	However, it sometimes gets unrealistic. For example, during the carriage chase, when other horseback riders appear, the only real option is to shoot the riders, and not the horses. I've emptied guns into those animals, but the game doesn't let them die because the developers have made it clear that this is not how the game is meant to be played. The flipside of this is that they can be used as instant barricades to take cover behind, and I did this several times when playing on the hard difficulty.	The best examples, I feel, are the stealth sections as Billy. For most of them, you are not allowed to kill the people you are trying to avoid, essentially making it forced stealth, because they also happen to be innocent, and the entire first half of the game is Billy fleeing from a false murder accusation. However, there's one part, where he has just escaped from town, and the people he has to avoid are criminals. THEN, he has other options.	This game excels at depth of gunplay, and it does so without feeling insulting or overpowering to the player. There is no lock-on, unlike in many other games of the genre. Slow motion is used, sure, but only when it makes sense, such as duels, or to give the player a small advantage in combat. Multitasking is rewarded immensely via the full akimbo shooting. The weapons are all unique, and each has its own practical application; I found myself voluntarily using every type of weapon the game provided to staisfy certain combat situations. However, because the guns degrade and eventually break from continuous use, the player will sometimes have to make use of unpreferable alternatives just to survive. It's all enough to keep the shootouts tense, and that's what really matters. That's when the game is at its best, when the player is ducking in and out of cover with extremely responsive controls to fend off hordes of enemies.	My biggest problem with the game is that it just feels lacking. It's difficult to put into words, because pretty much everything it does, it does well, but it never feels like it goes quite as far as it could. The levels often contain wide stretches of traversable land, but the objectives are fairly linear, so while it is possible to explore much of what there is to see, there is usually no reason to do so apart from (maybe) collecting some pickups. I had to play through it several times before I felt satisfied.	The multiplayer is also pretty dead nowadays. There aren't many populated servers, and most of the ones I found had pretty high ping. If you're getting this game, you're going to be sticking mainly to the single player, so thank heavens it's breddy gud.

												Before Dead Island brought Techland to the spotlight, they'd actually already released the fantastic Call of Juarez.Let's start with the negatives; the loading times are atrocious. I mean, you could probably fire up the game, go to the bathroom and take a dump and be back in time just to see the last centimeter of the loading bar filling up. The other negative is a technical issue, there's no option for vsync and it has to be forced on via d3doverdriver. I wasn't able to force it via AMD's CCC. Another negative would be the horse controls, not the best, but a good effort for a game from 2006.Now the positives; the story is a classic western tale. A young man comes home after months of searching for treasure and isn't exactly given a warm welcome. It only gets worse when he arrives at his farm to find his mother and step father dead. Billy is one of two protagonists, the other being Reverand Ray, the brother of Billy's step father. Switching between the two characters throughout the various episodes during the duration of the game sets up brilliant pacing with the story. As Ray hunts down Billy, believing he murdered his brother and in-law, you'll come across bandits and apache, various landscape of the massive western USA. From mountains and valleys, to the heat stricken Mexico. It's quite the adventure. What I really liked about the gameplay was the change in tone, Billy, being a slimmer character and less hardened, used stealth to sneak through levels, while Ray is the run and gun type while taking cover and strategizing. That's about it.9/10

												From the moment you start playing the game you can tell the studio was very ambitious and put a lot of heart into this western fps title, however, either due to their inexperience, budget constraints or some drunk binges between level and gameplay designers, they also created mechanics and levels that led to a lot of frustration.Throughout the campaign you play as either Billy or the Priest. They both play quite differently based on the mechanics and weapons they get in the levels. The Priest is where the meat of the game is. Fun, fast, frantic shoot em up action with slo mo, dual pistols, shotguns and rifles and the occasional stand off western style(which is pretty meh because its timed and thus you know exactly when the opponent is about to shoot). As a counterpoint to that, to let the player take a breather, Billy gets the levels where he has to stealth and platform. This would be fine, except both elements are pretty flawed. Stealth is mostly fine and will provide little to no challenge as you can sneak by anyone as long as they're not looking directly at you, however platforming is really really bad. First of all, you get a whip which you can use to attach to trees. The hit detection is very poor and you'll often only be able to use it only specific branches or trunk of a tree, which sometimes turns it into a tedious guessing game. The whip is also a missed opportunity as you could have used it in clever ways in combat to reposition enemies and grab items, but ultimately its for swinging from trees. Then the very worst part of platforming is that an animation plays out every time you reach for a ledge and Billy makes a noise. Now, in the early levels thats fine, if a bit annoying. BUT. Some level designer decides to a create a whole mission around you climbing a mountain. Now imagine that you have to wait for an animation and sound to play out as you're climbing 30-40 ledges, sometimes up to 6 in a row.The only redeemable quality about Billy is that he gets to use the bow, which is one of the best and most fun to use weapons in the game as you slow down time when you aim with it and its fun to take out enemies from a long range. Now, i mentioned that you had to a climb a mountain. That mission is part of series of bizzare quests involving a shaman thats easily the worst part of the game. You have to hunt 3 rabbits, which would be fine if they weren't REALLY REALLY SMALL, and some of the areas you're supposed to find them have grass twice as big as the rabbit. Even after the string of horrible shaman related quests, most of Billys quests after that resolve around platforming and solving puzzles all of a sudden, it takes a bizzare turn, as if the developers didn't know what to do with the character and the approach they were taking.Besides the mentioned shaman quests which have pretty poor level design, you will also be revisiting the same levels with both characters for the majority of the game(due to budget constraints im guessing), which also makes me think that the shaman quests were implemented just to extend the playing time.Talking more on the side the pros than cons, as I mentioned, it's really fun to play as the Priest Ray and the horse riding and horse combat in this fps is surprisingly really really good, which makes for exciting chase scenes. The game also creates an immersive atmoshphere and has a passable story. Billy isn't really likeable as a character, but Ray is definitely the highlight in the story, a flawed man on his own path to redemption, his voice acting really stands out as one of the best I've heard in a game ever, and stands tall above the passable voice acting of the other characters. It's grizzly and haunting.Overall, it's hard to recommend the game to everyone. I can see that playing as Billy could really turn some people off this game and the levels in which you play as him become more flawed as you go along, but the Ray segments are all fun shoot em up segments, and evne Billys levels have some exciting moments. It's definitely flawed, but if you can get past that it's a short, fun campaign.

												This is an excellent but short FPS along the lines of Half Life, but in a faithful western setting.While old, it has aged well and runs completely bug free in 4K under Windows 10. Posted: January 11, 2014
												There's an equation in the gaming industry that every developer seems to believe: popular genre A + popular genre b = awesome!  In practice, sometimes this is true (first person tower defense games are ok), but in the case of Call of Juarez, it simply leads to jumbled, subpar gameplay.  It's not even fair to say that Call of Juarez is a hybrid, it's basically two different games in the same shell tied together with a crappy story.  You could get much the same experience by playing a level of Thief, and then playing a level of Call of Duty.  Well, sort of, both of those games are much better designed than their respective segments in Call of Juarez.  Starting with the sneaky bits, in Call of Juarez there doesn't appear to be all that much actual sneaking.  Apparently to the developers, jumping out of windows is the same as sneaking, because you do that an awful lot.  Even if you do manage to sneak past your enemies, the game will just have them find you anyway at the next set piece.  Also, a hallmark of sneaking games is the relatively open level design and expectation that you'll find your own way around.  Call of Juarez thinks you're too stupid to handle open levels, so the everything is just linear with a couple of crate puzzles thrown in.The shooting bits are hardly any better.  Every shooter has to have its AWESOME SHOOTER MECHANIC THAT NO ONE HAS EVER DONE BEFORE to differentiate itself, and in the case of Call of Juarez, it's a quickdraw mechanic.  In practice, this is sort of the wild west version of bullet time from Max Payne except for the fact that your character can't hit the broad side of a barn.  In most fpses I can crack off head shot after head shot, but the controls are so soft in this game that I'm lucky if I manage to shoot in the general direction of my foes.There's not to say there aren't some cool things about this game.  For one, you play as a preacher for the shooty bits, and there's nothing cooler than a preacher with guns.

												Call of Juarez, formerly known as The Lawman is an western first-person shooter developed by Techland and published by Ubisoft in 2006-2007.In Call of Juarez you play two sides of the coin, on one side you play as Billy Candle and on the other as Reverend Ray. Billy Candle is an half-white, half-Mexican in search for the legendary lost gold of Juarez, a treasure hidden somewhere inside this city. When Billy is not capable of finding this treasure, he decides to go home to pay a visit to his mother and stepfather at the farm. On arrival, Billy is confronted with the death of his parents, murdered. The other character, Reverend Ray is Billy's step uncle and preacher. Ray is an reformed revolver hero who is dedicated to spreading the tales of The Lord, but when he hears about the commotion at the farm of his brother, he is going to pay a visit as well and sees Billy being panicked and Billy runs away from the dead bodies. Ray thinks Billy is responsible and promises Revenge and start hunting down Billy as long as he can.During the storyline, the game switches from character now and then. The game knows several features such as akimbo (wearing double weapons), sneaking, climbing by rope, revolver duels and bullet-time where you have to time and mark your shots at your enemies in order to finish them off quickly in the end. You also have to deal with several types of enemies like bandits, Apache Indians, Mexicans and several landlords. I really like this game because of the western atmosphere, the smooth switch between characters that initiate a story cliffhanger at the end of each chapter, the wild gunpowder action, voice acting, traveling by foot or horse and the vast landscapes from the rocky mountains, lurid towns and barren tundras filled with various wild animals.I highly recommend this game to people who like western first-person shooters with a very good storyline and large areas, certainly when the game is on sale!
